cluster.display: __________ random variables have a fixed number of independent trials, notated n.
Binomial random variables have a fixed number of __________ trials, notated n.
Binomial random variables have a fixed number of independent trials, notated __________.
Binomial random variables have a __________ probability of success for each trial, notated p.
Binomial random variables have a constant probability of __________ for each trial, notated p.
Binomial random variables have a constant probability of success for each trial, notated __________.
Binomial random variables have a constant __________ of success for each trial, notated p.
Binomial random variables have __________ n and p.
Binomial random variables have parameters __________ and p.
Binomial random variables have parameters n and __________.
For binomial random variables, __________ notates the number of successful trials.
For binomial random variables, k notates the number of __________ trials.
To find the number of possible outcomes in the __________ of a binomial random variable with exactly k successes, we divide n! by k!(n-k)!
To find the number of possible outcomes in the sample space of a binomial random variable with exactly k successes, we divide __________ by k!(n-k)!
To find the number of possible outcomes in the sample space of a binomial random variable with exactly k __________, we divide n! by k!(n-k)!
To find the number of possible __________ in the sample space of a binomial random variable with exactly k successes, we divide n! by k!(n-k)!
The __________ of a binomial random variable (μ<sub>X</sub>) equals np, or the number of trials multiplied by the probability.
The mean of a binomial random variable (μ<sub>X</sub>) equals __________ or the number of trials multiplied by the probability.
cluster.response: np|n times p|n\*p~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is np.
cluster.display: The mean of a binomial random variable (μ<sub>X</sub>) equals np, or the number of trials multiplied by the __________.
The mean of a binomial random variable (μ<sub>X</sub>) equals np, or the number of __________ multiplied by the probability.
The __________ of a binomial random variable equals np(1-p).
The variance of a binomial random variable equals __________(1-p).
The variance of a binomial random variable equals np(__________).
A probability __________ is used to represent the probability distribution of continuous random variables.
A probability density curve is used to represent the probability __________ of continuous random variables.
A probability density curve is used to represent the probability distribution of __________ random variables.
The total __________ under a probability density curve will always equal 1.
The total area under a probability density curve will always equal __________.
The __________ of a distribution of a continuous random variable is determined by its mean.
The center of a distribution of a __________ random variable is determined by its mean.
The center of a distribution of a continuous random variable is determined by its __________.
The __________ of a distribution of a continuous random variable is determined by its standard deviation.
The spread of a __________ of a continuous random variable is determined by its standard deviation.
The spread of a distribution of a continuous random variable is determined by its __________.
The __________ rule explains how the distribution of a normal random variable behaves relative to its mean and __________.
The standard deviation rule explains how the distribution of a normal random variable behaves relative to its __________ and standard deviation.
The __________ rule explains how the distribution of a normal random variable behaves relative to its mean and __________.
__________% of a normal variable X will fall within one standard deviation of its mean.
68% of a normal variable X will fall within __________ standard deviation of its mean.
68% of a normal variable X will fall within one standard deviation of its __________.
__________% of a normal variable X will fall within two standard deviations of its mean.
95% of a normal variable X will fall within __________ standard deviations of its mean.
95% of a normal variable X will fall within two __________ of its mean.
__________% of a normal variable X will fall within three standard deviations of its mean.
99.7% of a normal variable X will fall within __________ standard deviations of its mean.
99.7% of a normal variable X will fall within three standard deviations of its __________.
A __________ is a standardized value that tells us how many standard deviations above or below the mean a value is.
A z score is a standardized value that tells us how many standard deviations __________ or below the mean a value is.
A z score is a standardized value that tells us how many standard deviations above or below the __________ a value is.
A z score is a __________ value that tells us how many standard deviations above or below the mean a value is.
To calculate a z score, we subtract the __________ from the value x and divide value that by the standard deviation.
To calculate a __________, we subtract the mean from the value x and divide value that by the standard deviation.
To calculate a z score, we subtract the mean from the value x and divide value that by the __________.
__________ tables tell us the probability of a normal variable taking a value less than any z score.
Normal tables tell us the probability of a normal variable taking a value __________ than any z score.
Normal tables tell us the probability of a normal variable taking a value less than any __________.
We can approximate the probabilities for a __________ random variable using a normal random variable with the same mean and standard deviation as long as the sample size is large enough.
We can approximate the probabilities for a binomial random variable using a __________ random variable with the same mean and standard deviation as long as the sample size is large enough.
We can approximate the probabilities for a binomial random variable using a normal random variable with the same mean and standard deviation as long as the __________ is large enough.
